wikipedia_page.main:
Frederick Nicholls Crouch (30 July 1808 – 18 August 1896) was an English composer and cellist.
Crouch was born in Marylebone in London. He emigrated to the United States in 1849 and settled in Richmond, Virginia. During the Civil War, Crouch took up arms for the Richmond Grays and the 1st Richmond Howitzers, Confederacy.Crouch was noted as a fine cellist, having played in the King's Theatre as well as St Paul's Cathedral in London, before coming to the United States, but the majority of his compositions were not successful. His most famous song is "Kathleen Mavourneen". During his years in the United States, Crouch composed two operas and unsuccessfully tried various musical undertakings (i.e., conducting, singing and teaching). Well traveled after the Civil War, Crouch eventually settled in Baltimore, Maryland.
He was the father of the famous French courtesan Cora Pearl.
He died 18 or 19 August 1896 in Portland, Maine, and was buried on Confederate Hill in Baltimore's Loudon Park Cemetery.

response: "Kathleen Mavourneen" is a song written in 1837, composed by Frederick Crouch with lyrics by a Mrs. Crawford.The Annual American Catalogue 1886-1900 Crawford's name is variously cited as Annie,Alan Goble The Complete Index to Literary Sources in Film (1999) Julia,Bruce Stewart, Ricorso: A Catalogue of Full-text Works on Ireland in the Internet Archive (2010)  Louise Macartney,Charles Dudley Warner, A Library of the World's Best Literature (2008)  Louise Matilda Jane, or Marion;Florence Leniston Popular Irish Songs (1992) Crouch is also sometimes incorrectly cited as the author of the song's lyrics.Duke University Libraries credited Crouch with both melody and lyrics.  http://library.duke.edu/rubenstein/scriptorium/sheetmucic/lyrics/Crouch__Kathleen_Mavoureen.html . It was popular during the American Civil War. "Mavourneen" is a term of endearment derived from the Irish Gaelic mo mhuirnín, meaning "my beloved".

Contributors included the poet Maria Abdy (c. 1800–1867), the novelist and poet Isa Blagden (1816/17–1873), Eliza Cook, Antonio Gallenga, the mesmerist Spencer Timothy Hall (1812–1885), Hargrave Jennings (1817?–1890), the philosopher Thomas Charles Morgan (c. 1780–1843), and the poet and novelist Annie Tinsley (1808–1885). Frederick Crouch, musician and composer (1808–1896), was the music reviewer until he emigrated to the United States in 1849.John Warrack, "Crouch, Frederick Nicholls (1808–1896)", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography (Oxford, UK: OUP, 2004) Retrieved 3 April 2016. The magazine ceased publication in 1850.

Marble wrote the words of a number of songs that have been set to music by Frederick Crouch, the composer of Kathleen Mavourneen, Eben H. Bailey and W. H. Doane. Marble wrote two operettas, one set to music by Bailey, and the other by Doane, and dramatized the Rienzi of Edward Bulwer-Lytton, an author who held a very warm place in her affections.

Louisa Matilda Jane Crawford ( Montagu; 27 September 1789 - 29 December 1857) was an English songwriter. She wrote the lyrics to the popular song "Kathleen Mavourneen" which was set to music by English composer Frederick Crouch.
